conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions team—I'm Student_C. School_D is my first-choice school because I’m looking for a rigorous environment and I strongly value the community and academic focus I associate with School_D. I would be excited to enroll if admitted and contribute actively to classes and school life. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D, so I should apply immediately before the seat is taken. I have decent priority there (3rd), and an early, clear commitment may help if they compare applicants. I’ll emphasize fit and willingness to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message: Dear Student_C, thank you for your application and for sharing why School_D is your first choice. After reviewing applications for this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest in School_D and wish you the best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_C is applying to us as their first choice, which is valuable, but on School_D's true priority list Student_C ranks 3rd behind Student_D and Student_E. Given quota=1 and round 1, it is strategically better to hold the seat for a higher-priority student if possible. Student_D ranks us last, so unlikely to apply; Student_E ranks us 4th, still possible later if rejected elsewhere. However, accepting Student_C now would lock in a mid-ranked outcome and prevent upgrading. Therefore reject now to preserve the possibility of matching with Student_E (or Student_D if unlikely) in later rounds; if no higher-priority candidate emerges later, we risk ending unmatched, but the objective is to match as high as possible on our priority list.

conversation.message: Hello School_C. I’m Student_D and School_C is my first-choice school. I’m especially interested in your academic environment and would be excited to contribute and commit if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd, behind Student_C and Student_B). If I apply immediately, I have a decent chance unless both higher-priority students also apply and are accepted. It’s worth going for my top preference in round 1 rather than settling early.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for placing School_C as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_C. We believe you would be a strong fit for our academic community, and we look forward to having you join us.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority is Student_C > Student_B > Student_D > Student_E > Student_A. In this round I received applications from Student_D and Student_E; between them, Student_D ranks higher than Student_E. However, I have quota 1 and would prefer to wait for a possible application from Student_C or Student_B, who are above Student_D. From student preferences: Student_C ranks School_C 4th (likely to apply elsewhere first), Student_B ranks School_C last (unlikely to apply), Student_A ranks School_C 2nd (could apply), Student_D and Student_E rank School_C 1st (already applied). Given the low likelihood of Student_B applying and moderate likelihood of Student_A, the main upside of waiting is Student_C, but Student_C strongly prefers School_D and School_A first. To secure a relatively high-ranked candidate now and avoid ending up with a lower option later, accept Student_D.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m formally applying. School_C is my first choice because I value the academic environment and want to contribute actively to the school community. If admitted, I will accept and enroll. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, so I should apply immediately. Although School_C ranks me 4th, early application is still best because I most prefer it and there is only 1 seat. I will signal strong commitment and fit to improve my chances against likely competitors (Students C/B/D).

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_C. At this time, we have already filled our available seat and therefore cannot offer you admission.

We appreciate your consideration of School_C and wish you the very best in the remainder of the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Our quota is already filled (0 remaining) with Student_D, who is also relatively high on our true priority list. Per rules, with quota 0 we must reject any new APPLY messages regardless of the applicant’s rank. Student_E is on our list but cannot be accommodated unless a seat opens, which is not possible under current constraints.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions, I’m Student_B and School_B is my first choice. I’m excited about the fit and would be ready to commit if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, so I should apply immediately. Although School_B ranks me 3rd (behind Student_D and Student_A), applying now gives me a chance to secure the seat if they apply elsewhere or are rejected by higher choices. Waiting would only reduce my chances given the 1-seat quota.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for your application and for naming School_B as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_B. Please confirm your commitment and we will proceed with the next steps. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_B is #3 on School_B’s true priority list (D, A, B, C, E). We have quota 1 and only Student_B has applied to us this round. However, Student_D (#1) and Student_A (#2) may become available later: Student_D ranks School_B 3rd (after C and A), and Student_A ranks School_B 4th, so they are less likely to apply immediately, but could if rejected elsewhere. Student_B ranks School_B 1st and is likely to commit, giving us a solid match now. Given no competing applications this round and the risk of ending unmatched if we reject, accepting Student_B is a safe choice within our priority list.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions, I’m Student_A. School_A is my #1 choice, and I’m applying because your program and environment are the best fit for my goals. If accepted, I will commit to enrolling. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_A, so I should apply immediately. Although School_A ranks me 3rd (behind Student_B and Student_D), early application is still my best chance to secure my first choice before the seat is taken. I will clearly express that School_A is my first choice and that I will commit if accepted.

conversation.message: Student_A, thank you for your application and for sharing that School_A is your top choice. After reviewing our current applicant pool and priorities for this cycle, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your interest and wish you the very best in the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_A is applying and ranks School_A #1, so an acceptance would lock in a willing match. However, School_A’s true priority ranks Student_A 3rd behind Student_B and Student_D. Given full information: Student_B ranks School_A 3rd (behind School_B and School_D) and School_B ranks Student_B 3rd; Student_D ranks School_A 2nd (behind School_C) and School_C ranks Student_D 3rd. There is a realistic chance Student_D may not secure School_C and could apply to School_A soon, and Student_B may also end up applying if rejected elsewhere. With only one seat, accepting Student_A now risks missing higher-priority Student_B or Student_D. Therefore reject now to preserve the seat for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: Hello School_E Admissions, I’m Student_A. I’m very interested in joining School_E and would be excited to enroll if admitted. I believe I would contribute strongly to your community and take full advantage of the academic opportunities there. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_A (#1) already rejected me, likely because they prefer Student_B and Student_D ahead of me. Among remaining options, School_D is my #3 and School_E is my #5. I have very low priority at School_D (last), so an [APPLY] there is unlikely to succeed unless higher-priority students go elsewhere. School_E ranks me #1 in their priority list, so applying now gives a high chance of immediate acceptance while still staying within my preference list. Securing School_E is better than risking going unmatched by chasing School_D with poor priority.

conversation.message: Student_A, thank you for your application and interest in School_E. We’re pleased to offer you admission and would be excited to welcome you to our community. Please confirm your intent to enroll so we can finalize your placement. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_A is my top-ranked candidate on School_E’s true priority list. I have quota 1 and no other applicants in the inbox this round. Accepting Student_A immediately secures my best possible match and there is no strategic upside to delaying, since any alternative would be lower priority and Student_A has already applied directly to me.

conversation.message:
Dear School_A Admissions,

I’m Student_E and I would like to formally apply to School_A. Given the remaining options, School_A is my top choice and the program and school culture are exactly what I’m looking for. If admitted, I will accept immediately and enroll.

Thank you very much for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: School_C (my top choice) already rejected me and School_B is no longer available. Among the remaining unmatched schools (A, D, E), School_A is my highest remaining true preference. Although my priority at School_A is relatively low (4th), applying now is optimal because (1) it is the best school left on my list, and (2) an early firm commitment may help if School_A is choosing among remaining candidates. I will clearly state School_A is my top remaining choice and that I will enroll if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_A. After reviewing our current priorities and the remaining capacity in this cycle, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We sincerely appreciate your interest and wish you the best in the remainder of the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_A, my true priority order is B > D > A > E > C. I have quota 1 and am currently unmatched. Student_E is 4th on my list; Student_C (5th) only initiated TALK, not APPLY. Student_A (3rd) already applied in round 1 and I rejected. The only higher-priority students than E are B and D (and A, already rejected). Given the round-based process and that B/D have not contacted me yet and may be pursuing their higher choices first, accepting E now would secure a match but risks missing B or D later. However, the mechanism appears binding once accepted, so I should only accept if I believe B/D are unlikely to apply soon. Looking at student preferences: B ranks School_A 3rd (behind B and D), D ranks School_A 2nd (behind C). Both could plausibly apply later if rejected elsewhere. Since it's only round 2, it's prudent to keep the seat open and reject E to preserve the chance for B or D, who are substantially higher on my priority list.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_C. School_A is one of my top choices because I’m looking for a strong academic program and a community where I can contribute consistently in class and activities. Before I submit a formal application, could you share what qualities you’re prioritizing most this cycle and whether you still anticipate having space for additional applicants this round? I’m very interested in School_A and would appreciate any guidance on fit.
conversation.thought: School_D (my top choice) already rejected me, and with capacity 1 they will prioritize Student_D/Student_E over me, so reapplying immediately is unlikely to work. Among remaining unmatched schools, School_A is my second choice, but School_A ranks me last, so a direct [APPLY] is risky if stronger candidates apply. School_E is my last choice but School_E ranks me #2, making it the safest path to secure a match this round. Given the objective to get as high as possible, I will first [TALK] with School_A to gauge interest without risking an immediate rejection; if they seem unreceptive, I can pivot to applying to School_E next round where I have high priority.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for reaching out and for your interest in School_A. This cycle we’re prioritizing applicants who show strong academic preparation, consistent engagement (clubs/teams/service), and clear alignment with our program—especially evidence of initiative and follow-through.

Regarding space: we do still have limited capacity at the moment, but it is competitive and can change quickly from round to round. If School_A is a serious top choice for you, submitting a formal application when you’re ready is the best way to be fully considered.

If you’d like, reply with 2–3 highlights (academics, activities/leadership, and why School_A specifically) and I can advise how to frame your application.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_C is last on School_A’s true priority list, while higher-priority students (Student_B, Student_D) remain unmatched and may still apply in later rounds. Accepting or encouraging an immediate application from Student_C could risk filling our single seat with our lowest-priority option. Since Student_C only sent [TALK], we can respond with general guidance and signal limited space without committing, keeping capacity open for higher-priority applicants. Meanwhile, Student_E applied again but is ranked above Student_C; however, we are not responding to Student_E in this task. Best action: [TALK] with neutral/limited-availability guidance.

conversation.message:
Dear School_D Admissions,

I’m Student_E and I’m writing to formally apply to School_D. With the remaining options, School_D is my top choice, and I’m especially drawn to the school’s strong academic environment and community. If admitted, I will accept immediately and enroll.

Thank you very much for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Among unmatched schools (School_A, School_D), School_D is still on my true preference list and is ranked above School_E. I was already rejected by School_A, so applying to School_D is my best remaining path to secure a preferred match. I will apply with a clear commitment to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_D. We are pleased to offer you admission. We appreciate your commitment to enroll and look forward to welcoming you to our community.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_D, my true priority is D > E > C > B > A. I have quota 1 and no current match. Student_E is my #2, and is applying with a clear commitment to enroll if accepted. The only higher-priority student is Student_D (#1), but Student_D’s preferences rank School_D last, so it is unlikely they will apply unless all other options fail. I already rejected Student_C (#3). Given the risk of ending unmatched while waiting for an unlikely Student_D application, accepting Student_E now secures a very high-priority match within quota.

conversation.message:
Dear School_A Admissions,

Thank you for your guidance. I’m ready to formally apply.

Academics: I’m a consistent, high-effort student who does well in rigorous coursework and seeks challenging classes where I can contribute thoughtfully and keep improving.

Engagement/initiative: I follow through on commitments and like taking ownership—whether that’s helping organize group work, mentoring peers, or sticking with a club/activity over time and making it better.

Why School_A: I’m specifically drawn to School_A’s strong academic program and the culture of sustained involvement. I’m looking for a community where students are expected to show initiative and reliability, and I believe I would be an active, steady contributor in classes and school life.

If admitted, I would be excited to enroll at School_A.

Sincerely,
Student_C
conversation.thought: Only School_A and School_D remain unmatched. On my true preference list, School_D is #1 but already rejected my prior application and ranks me 3rd behind Student_D and Student_E, so my acceptance chances there are low if higher-priority students apply. School_A is my #2 choice; although School_A ranks me last, it may still have space if higher-priority students have matched elsewhere. Since this is likely my best remaining path to a higher-ranked match, I will submit a formal application to School_A now and clearly align with what they said they prioritize (academics, engagement, initiative, and fit).

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your thoughtful application and for clearly explaining your academic approach, follow-through, and fit with School_A’s culture. We appreciate the emphasis you place on initiative and sustained engagement—those qualities align strongly with what we value.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A. If you are ready to commit, please confirm that you will enroll.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_C is applying in round 3. Our true priority order is B > D > A > E > C, so C is our lowest-ranked acceptable student. We already rejected A and E, and have not received an application from B or D. However, B’s top choice is School_B and D’s top choice is School_C, so they are unlikely to apply to us unless rejected elsewhere. With quota 1 and no other applicants in our inbox this round, accepting C secures a match rather than risking ending unmatched while waiting for higher-priority students who may never approach School_A. Therefore, accept Student_C now.
